questions.text: Loud first heart sound (S1) in mitral stenosis indicates?

Match the following Condition Type of S2 Splitting 1) Wide Split a) RBBB 2) Paradoxical Splitting b) Mitral regurgitation 3) Fixed Splitting c) LBBB 4) Narrow Split d) Pulmonary artery hypertension e) ASD
questions.explanation:
Condition

Type of Split

1)Wide split

Mitral regurgitation

2)Paradoxical split

LBBB

3)Fixed Splitting

ASD

4)Narrowed splitting

Pulmonary artery hypertension

Wide Splitting
  • Occurs in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) due to delayed pulmonic valve closure.
  • Seen in severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to premature closure of the aortic valve- Wide and variable split is seen.

Narrow Splitting or Singular S2
  • Narrow Splitting- E.g. Aortic stenosis or Singular S2

Wide Fixed Splitting
  • The A2-P2 interval is wide and does not change during the respiratory cycle. E.g.- ASD, TAPVC, RVF

Reversed or Paradoxical Splitting- P2 before A2
  • Seen in conditions such as left bundle branch block (LBBB).
  • Right ventricular pacing.
  • Severe aortic stenosis (AS).
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM),
  • Acute myocardial ischemia.

Loud P2
  • Considered loud when its intensity exceeds A2 at the base or can be palpated in the proximal main pulmonary artery area. E.g.- Pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Decreased Intensity
  • A2 intensity decreases with aortic stenosis (AS) and P2 intensity decreases with pulmonic stenosis (PS), potentially resulting in a single S2.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and occasional chest discomfort. He mentions that the episodes are sudden in onset and can last for several minutes before resolving spontaneously. His vitals are stable, and physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG of the condition is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
A 35-year-old woman presents with palpitations. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with soft S1 and pansystolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Sound

Timing

Mechanisms

Characteristics

Variable Features

First heart sound (S1)

Beginning of systole

Mitral and tricuspid valve closure

Typically single or slightly split
  • Loud in conditions like anemia, pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, mitral stenosis
  • Soft in heart failure, mitral regurgitation

Second heart sound (S2)

End of systole

Aortic and pulmonary valve closure (A2 first, P2 second)

Splits during inspiration; single on expiration
  • Fixed wide splitting with atrial septal defect
  • Wide variable splitting with delayed right heart emptying (RBBB)
  • Reversed splitting due to delayed left heart emptying (LBBB)

Third heart sound (S3)

Early diastole, after S2

Sudden deceleration of blood filling into ventricles

Low pitch, often heard as 'gallop'
  • Normal in young people and pregnancy
  • Pathological in heart failure, mitral regurgitation

Fourth heart sound (S4)

Late diastole, before S1

Atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle

Low pitch
  • Present in severe left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and diabetes presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. On physical examination, you hear both an S3 and an S4 heart sound. Which of the following best explains the presence of both heart sounds in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.correct_answer: C. Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has a history of tuberculosis treated 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that rises paradoxically with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Wave/ Descent

Refers

Clinical Significance

a Wave
  • Atrial contraction (right atrium), follows the P wave on ECG and precedes S1
  • Prominent in RV compliance issues
  • Early Prominent- Tricuspid stenosis
  • Late Prominent- Mitral stenosis
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation
  • Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia.

x Descent
  • Fall in right atrial pressure post-a wave, reflecting atrial relaxation
  • Dominant in normal jugular venous pulses.
  • Prominent- Cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis
  • Absent- Tricuspid Regurgitation

c Wave
  • Occurs during ventricular systole, tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium
  • Seen in the ventricular systole
  • Can coincide with a carotid pulse.

v Wave
  • Passive Atrial filling after ventricular systole follows S2
  • Prominent in tricuspid regurgitation (TR)
  • In severe TR, the C wave may merge with the V wave, creating a "ventricularized" waveform—a giant V or CV wave.

y Descent
  • Fall in right atrial pressure after tricuspid valve opening
  • Absent in pericardial tamponade
  • Prominent in constrictive pericarditis or severe TR.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows an unequal number of P waves and R waves and his jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing is shown below. Which of the following conditions is responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation:
a Wave
  • Occurs due to atrial contraction.
  • Follows P wave on ECG.
  • Precedes S1

Clinical Significance:

  • Prominent in reduced RV compliance
  • Absent in atrial fibrillation (Option A ruled out)
  • Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia.
    • They occur when the right atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, typically seen with AV dissociation.
    • In wide complex tachycardia, cannon ‘a’ waves in the jugular venous waveform suggest a ventricular origin of the rhythm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung presents with sudden dyspnoea, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals elevated JVP and an abnormal drop of 15mm Hg in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. An ECG was performed and is given below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
Which of the following schematic represents murmur of mitral stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Narrowing of the mitral valve, usually due to rheumatic disease, causing obstruction to blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle

Symptoms
  • Breathlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Oedema, ascites
  • Palpitation
  • Haemoptysis
  • Cough
  • Chest pain
  • Thromboembolism

Systolic murmurs

Diastolic murmurs

Midsystolic

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Pulmonic stenosis
  • Atrial septal defect
  • HOCM

Early diastolic

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Pulmonic regurgitation
  • Austin-Flint

Holosystolic

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • VSD

Mid/late diastolic

  • Mitral stenosis
  • Tricuspid stenosis

Late systolic murmur

  • Mitral valve prolapse

Other rare murmurs

  • Patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a loud, high-pitched murmur heard best at the apex of the heart, radiating to the axilla. The intensity of the murmur does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of high blood pressure detected during a routine check-up. On physical examination, the blood pressure is higher in the arms compared to the legs. A continuous murmur is heard over the back, near the left scapula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Coarctation of the Aorta 
  • Narrowing occurs where the ductus arteriosus connects to the aorta, distal to the left subclavian artery.
  • Causes elevated blood pressure above the narrowing (upper limbs) and reduced blood pressure below it (legs).

Clinical Features
  • Can cause cardiac failure in newborns but may be asymptomatic in older children or adults.
  • Hypertension above narrowing may cause headaches; reduced blood flow below may lead to leg cramps or weakness.
  • Radio-femoral delay.
  • A continuous murmur is typically heard over the back near the left scapula.
  • Additional sound (ejection click) may be heard in the aortic area if a bicuspid aortic valve is present.
  • Collateral circulation develops through periscapular, internal mammary, and intercostal arteries, sometimes causing localized bruits

questions.text: Match the Following Murmurs to Their Characteristics or Associated Conditions Murmurs Characteristics or Associated Conditions 1. Mitral Stenosis A. High-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. 2. Aortic Stenosis B. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, often with a displaced apical impulse. 3. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) C. Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border. 4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy D. "Machine-like" continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area. 5. Mitral Regurgitation E. Loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. 6. Aortic Regurgitation F. Systolic ejection murmur, often with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids.
questions.explanation:
Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex. Accentuated by exercise or Valsalva's maneuver. 

Aortic Stenosis

Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids

Patent Ductus Arteriosus

A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern

Mitral Regurgitation

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Graham Steell Murmur

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border.

Austin Flint Murmur

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle.

Carvallo's Sign

Increased intensity of a tricuspid regurgitation murmur with inspiration, heard along the left lower sternal border.
